messages: a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:54): http://dvcs.w3.org/hg/ime-api/raw-file/default/use-cases/Overview.html
dc31aa4ef57dda64b229b2d96a4a0031 (12:57): comes looking for edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e, long time :-)

dc31aa4ef57dda64b229b2d96a4a0031 (12:59): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e, people have been advocating putting Access-Control-Allow-Origin:* indiscriminately into response headers based on the CORS spec
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (13:00): hey man
dc31aa4ef57dda64b229b2d96a4a0031 (13:00): I think it makes sense to do so, but when I read the spec, it seems to me it doesn't allow it
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (13:00): oh
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (13:00): it's allowed for sure
dc31aa4ef57dda64b229b2d96a4a0031 (13:00): oh, ok
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (13:00): and it's safe, too
dc31aa4ef57dda64b229b2d96a4a0031 (13:00): yeah, it amounts to saying "actually, I don't care"
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (13:01): unless it's an intranet resource or some such
dc31aa4ef57dda64b229b2d96a4a0031 (13:01): right
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (13:01): then it's not safe
dc31aa4ef57dda64b229b2d96a4a0031 (13:02): so, I suppose it is the start of 5.1 that is a bit confusing
dc31aa4ef57dda64b229b2d96a4a0031 (13:02): since if I just follow the link to "simple cross-origin request", then, yes, it seems to be allowed
dc31aa4ef57dda64b229b2d96a4a0031 (13:02): but if I just read on, then it seems it is conditional on the request Origin header
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (13:03): should clarify that I guess
dc31aa4ef57dda64b229b2d96a4a0031 (13:03): would be nice
dc31aa4ef57dda64b229b2d96a4a0031 (13:05): was about to create som Plack middleware for it, but sees it has already been done
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (13:06): cool
dc31aa4ef57dda64b229b2d96a4a0031 (13:09): pings his favorite Debian developer about it instead
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (13:10): i think i'm gonna water down the server requirements
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (13:11): they are rough guidelines for certain scenarios, but servers can really do whatever the fuck they want
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (13:11): it doesn't matter
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (13:11): as long as the clients are compliant everything should be good
dc31aa4ef57dda64b229b2d96a4a0031 (13:11): any timeline for it to go to Rec?
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (13:12): I don't really care, but people seem to try to push it to Last Call
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (13:12): so, couple more years maybe...
dc31aa4ef57dda64b229b2d96a4a0031 (13:12): hehe
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (13:12): it's not going to change
dc31aa4ef57dda64b229b2d96a4a0031 (13:13): would have liked a normative reference from the SPARQL 1.1 Protocol, but that's happening RSN :-)
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:26): Exorcising DTDs with RDFa: http://www.w3.org/News/2012.html#entry-9353
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (13:30): wasn't there a DTD for RDFa+HTML?
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (13:38): cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0: yeah, there is still
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (13:38): no, not for RDFa+HTML specifically
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (13:38): not currently at least afaik
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (13:38): they do have a DTD in the RDF Core 1.1 spec
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:39): cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0: there have been various RDFa + some legacy deliverable of the XHTML2 WG
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (13:41): I seriously think we should have a policy that bans WGs from publishing any new DTDs

a1fbe72f47651e50181e743dc550aeee (13:41): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: I think it is dangerous to suggest that a content author would have sufficient knowledge to determine whether a particular phrase might be untranslatable in another language; this differs from specifically asserting that something should not be translated, as a name or technical term.
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (13:42): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: I've pushed all changes upstream
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (13:42): thank you man
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (13:43): http://dev.w3.org/html5/rdfa/#validation

a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (13:44): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: btw, if you happen to (re)look at the changesets, probably best to look in reverse chronological order, because I ending up backing out/reverting much of the initial changes
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:44): cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0: that's an HTML WG deliverable, so it can be put through the Decision Process
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (13:44): yeah
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (13:44): i guess I missed that part of the spec :(
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:45): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: the validator doesn't start due to schema errors
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (13:45): yeah
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (13:45): please retry it
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (13:45): I found that too
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (13:45): I think it's due to the presets changing and the entity map needing to be rebuilt
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (13:45): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: sadly i've stopped caring about that kind of thing
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (13:46): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: but if that doesn't work, lemme know
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (13:46): i've objected to dtds being written and new doctypes being minted before with not so much success
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:47): Prediction: Wikipedia will cite Appendix B.1 as the truth despite its rules about primary sources.

c53ce266132145423a95034f111ad7dd (15:35): did this section get moved to a different spec? http://web.archive.org/web/20110123174457/http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/current-work/multipage/apis-in-html-documents.html#dom-innerhtml
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (15:35): yes
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (15:36): http://html5.org/specs/dom-parsing.html
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (15:36): long time ago
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (15:36): you should read the WHATWG Weekly :p
c53ce266132145423a95034f111ad7dd (15:36): i must‚Äôve missed that one :(
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (15:36): spread the news :)
c53ce266132145423a95034f111ad7dd (15:37): document.innerHTML used to be mentioned explicitly; has it been removed or does `element.innerHTML` imply it should also work for `document`?
c53ce266132145423a95034f111ad7dd (15:38): http://html5.org/specs/dom-parsing.html#innerhtml
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (15:38): Ms2ger killed it
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (15:38): and thereby broke XHR
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (15:38): he has yet to fix it somehow I believe
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (15:40): killed what? Document.innerHTML?
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (15:40): yeah
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (15:40): lack of implementations
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (15:40): DOMParser FTW
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (15:40): I thought it was useful personally
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (15:40): people are actually testing XHR + data URLs because they want async
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (15:41): iirc
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (15:41): have to ask the typlab guys again
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (15:41): XHR is nicer that DOMParser of course
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (15:41): in Gecko, it does stuff on another thread and doesn't lock the UI
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (15:42): using XHR seems kind of hackish to me
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (15:42): but well, if it works
